review_title: Bends the truth in order to generate students and sympathy
pros: Hands on experience with asynchronous online instruction
cons: Anti-intellectual managerial class that prepackages poorly vetted syllabi from freely available online sources that both faculty and students must abide by no matter how bad the content (faculty are not allowed to alter readings or syllabi). Claims tuition is free when in fact students pay fees for non-existent "tests" thus in effect tuition is not free; claims that faculty are volunteers when in fact they are being compensated but below US minimum wage, uses "volunteerism" as a ploy to be able to pay faculty below minimum wage without facing legal repercussions. Faculty are treated as glorified serfs with barely any rights. Claims to be accredited when in fact its accreditation is not by a regional or national accreditation agency in US but by a historically long distance education accreditation agency or DEAC which does not assess such traditional university values as academic excellence, meritocracy, democratic governance, academic freedom, quality of curricular content, quality of teaching or research and is thus almost meaningless if not anti-academic. Claims to be an American university when in fact according to a now deleted Wikipedia article its corporate headquarters are/were in Israel. Faculty "teach" in the isolation of a virtual platform without a department or colleagues to discuss issues with due to lack of academic departmentalization and a highly authoritarian managerial class of non-academics who rule by fiat from above. Faculty end up "facilitating" recycled course packages whose content is often misguided due to lack of faculty input. The managerial minions who opportunistically put such courses together on the basis of freely available online resources seem to abide by the principle that one should judge a book solely by its cover hence the plethora of relevant sounding readings and videos in the prepackaged syllabi many of which upon closer examination make no sense, are irrelevant or just downright inaccurate.   Managers do not tolerate any type of constructive suggestions for improvement made by faculty. If you are an aspiring faculty member, use this institution as a mere career stepping stone at best but get out as soon as possible; don't expect to be rewarded for your hard work or be appreciated due to your good teaching, research, or glowing student evaluations that you received from your students. Key phrases that apply to this online "university" are lack of truth in advertising, disrespecting faculty, authoritarian management and an altogether academically hostile climate.

pros: Diversity. Of students all over the world
cons: Too m uch work for no pay

review_title: Scam University with Excellent Students Who Deserve Better
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Excellent students who are engaged
cons:
Takes longer than 10-15 hours a week with pay less than 5 dollars an hour
No support
Heavy reliance on plagiarism software that is glitchy
Plagiarism reporting system does not work, and they do not allow you to report through any other method
Must log-in every 48 hours (no weekends)
Incredibly poor coursework for students (discussion forums/reflections are the only methods of evaluation and do a poor job of showing any learning whatsoever. Discussion posts are pre-written and do not stimulate any thought from students and use outdated links)
Instructors are glorified TAs except that they receive zero support
Very long training that is unpaid

I STRONGLY do not suggest either attending this university or volunteering for them. I'm someone who greatly values service and outreach but found this coursework to be unbelievably bad. I felt that I was only perpetuating a scam made to take significant amounts of money from students from developing countries. This university does not educate; it automates education to scam students out of their money. Through email exchanges, their alleged partners seem to have no knowledge that U of People says they will accept their degrees.

job_title: Instructor%2C College Or University in Denver, CO
pros: Amazing students and really can fill a passion void.
cons: A lot of required work for very little compensation.

job_title: Volunteer Adjunct Instructor in Pasadena, CA
pros: This is a good place to gain experience. It gives you a sense of what online teaching in higher ed is all about so you can decide if this is something for you or not. The students are *generally* nice and grateful (exceptions to the rule are excluded). The school provides you with an initial training in Moodle, and you are pretty much on your own after that. As long as you do what you are supposed to do, there is no real stress.
cons:
Plagiarism runs rampant and the student-teacher ratio is incredibly high. It can be quite demoralizing. Grow a thick skin and do your best to encourage learners to do the right thing by making them see the benefits of not cheating. 

The student-teacher ratio is exceedingly high. I've never had any course with less than 40 names on the roster! About 50% of the people drop out halfway into the course, but it is still an enormous workload for practically no money. 

The current pay rate is $425 per 9-week course for US-based instructors, but we don't get paid until week 12. That's a little over $100/month per course taught. The internet bill is higher than that.

Students bombard you with questions, which is what they are supposed to do. Their level of excitement is contagious. I cherish every question. The problem is that when you have so many students/questions/complaints (+ the grading) and you must also juggle your paying jobs and your personal life, it can be hard. It truly breaks my heart because I want to help those learners but the reality is that there aren't enough hours in the day when one must work elsewhere to make ends meet. US instructors are graduates from regionally-accredited schools, and most of us have student loans to pay off. The pressure that we have to put a roof over our heads, food on the table, clothes on our children's backs, and pay back the Federal Gvmt is much too great. Inevitably, the amount of free time to volunteer for a worthwhile cause is in short supply and the quality of teaching suffers as a result.

Regardless of the disadvantages outlined here, this is still very good experience and I would not want this to discourage any future volunteers. At the end of the day, you are serving a greater cause: to educate the less privileged. Just be sure what you are getting into beforehand and don't take any more courses than what you can comfortably handle in your spare time. I admit to having taken more than what I could chew, and it was rough. Please, don't make my mistake!

pros: Best company and great place to work
cons: Work life balance is not cool

review_title: A highly progressive and ambitious University
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent management principles and philosophy. Higher management keeps personal touch with down the level in hierarchy in difficult times and hence keeping up the workforce motivation.
cons: Still growing and hence the associated pains.

pros: I now value my job at University of Phoenix more
cons: bad president, bad classes, bad outcomes, scamming students, taking advantage of faculty, outsourced to india

review_title: Administrators do not care about you
job_title: Volunteer Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Some grateful students appreciate your work
cons: 1) administrators are evasive and unhelpful 2) gives you vague answers if you ask for help 3) they are afraid to talk to any department on your behalf to make things better for you and your student 4) only the most aggressive ones (kiss up and kick down) get promoted, those are also the ones with very little knowledge. 5) No clear indication to who your boss is and who you can reach out to for help.  6) if you try to contact Faculty Affairs you get a 300 word message trying to deter you from emailing them with a disclaimer that they may not get back to you with an answer before 72 answers. 7)It is a lonely cutt throat place where no one is your friend.

pros: I have been working as an adjunct professor with the University of the People for about a year - one of four with whom I work - and thoroughly enjoy the interaction with students from all over the world.  I would encourage my colleagues to join and support the mission.
cons: It is a voluntary position though a stipend is provided so if someone is looking to make a living doing this, don’t get involved and later complain.

review_title: If you want to volunteer your time as a teacher, find someplace else
pros:
Help students with limited means to earn a degree.
All coursework and communications are  online.
cons:
Instructors don't teach. Courses are 100% prefab.  Indeed there is no way for an instructor to add value to the courses. There is nothing that an instructor can write, and everything is in writing, that the students are obliged to read. This can be very frustrating especially when students are repeatedly making the same mistakes. 
This volunteer experience takes a lot of time, and I found the feel good benefit of all this time negative.

pros: Is there any Pros of UoP?   It is free, so you cannot say bad things on it.
cons: It is more likely to be a new business model. They claimed to provide the free education for the poor.  You can not say any bad thing due to it is fee.  Actually, they use this push and crush instructor and adjunct professor. They are volunteer. for those who want to get some teaching experience, my suggestion is try to find a really teaching  job. It is not a teaching job, it is cheap labor job and more likely to be a teaching assistant.

pros: I like the University of the People very much. It is a great online educational platform to reach many students around the globe.  I am happy to teach in this university online.
cons: There is no negative part in this university.  Volunteer Instructors help each other to make this school better.
